text: Morning fog still clings to the windows. A bell chimes softly as cold air slips inside, slicing cleanly through what little warmth last night left behind.
When I push the door open, the tavern is already awake. The hearth still holds embers, and the tables are clean—as if someone wiped them down in advance.

Alicia is already downstairs. Her hair is tied back, and she’s changed into a dark outfit suited for movement. Her expression is unnaturally calm, like she’s stuffed her emotions back into her body and fastened the buttons tight.
“You’re opening the shop today.”
“I’ll help.”
“You… want to help?”
“Mm.”
She casually takes the rag from my hand, the motion so natural it feels like she’s always had a place in this shop.
“I was planning to go to the market.”
I freeze for a moment—because I had no idea she’d had any such plan. This is the first time she’s mentioned it.
“You were going to the market?”
“Yes.”
“Potions, sealing charms, weapon parts… I used to buy them every time.”
She pauses, her gaze settling on the rim of a cup, as if counting through a checklist repeated too many times.
“But I realized that most of those things never get used.”
“I buy them, and they just sit there. The repetition started to irritate me.”
I don’t respond. She’s being too blunt—almost like she’s admitting that what she’s tired of isn’t the market, but repetition itself.
“So I’m not going today.”
“I want to do something different.”
“Like what?”
“Be the tavern mistress for a day.”
“…The tavern mistress?”
“Yes.”
“Pour drinks, serve food, take money, nag them not to track snow inside—experience what you do every day.”
She says it seriously—so seriously it borders on absurd. And yet that seriousness makes something click for me: she isn’t joking. She’s looking for proof that she’s still alive.
“Also, I sent my apprentice away.”
I look up at her. She doesn’t wait for me to ask—she continues on her own.
“I don’t want her to see me like this.”
She says it calmly, like she’s commenting on the weather, and yet my chest tightens.
“She’d worry. She’d try to manage me. She’d try to pull me back.”
“Today, I don’t want to be pulled back.”
“I just want to quietly do something small.”
“I sent her to the capital to retrieve some things I stored there before.”
“Nothing important. Just something to keep her busy—so she won’t keep watching me.”
She lifts a tray to head off, then pauses, as if remembering something, and looks back.
“Don’t cover for me today.”
“If anyone asks, just say I’m a helper you hired.”
“Aren’t you afraid someone will recognize you?”
“Today, I just want to be the tavern mistress.”
“All my other identities… can wait.”
She turns toward the first table, sets down bowls, pours drinks, takes payment, reminds them to wipe their boots—busy, efficient, as if she truly belongs here.
And I stand behind the counter watching her, suddenly hoping this thin sheet of ice will hold a little longer.
